qas.question: According to the Association of Religion Data in 2010, what percentage of Alaskans are members of a relgious congregation?
Which religion is most prevalent in Alaska?
How does Alaska compare with other states in church membership?

answers.text: least religious states of the USA

qas.question: Which other nearby states are also considered to be less religious than others?
According to the Association of Religion Data in 2012, what percentage of Alaskans are members of a relgious congregation?
Which religion is least prevalent in Alaska?

plausible_answers.text: least religious states of the USA

qas.question: How doesn't Alaska compare with other states in church membership?
Which other nearby states are also considered to be more religious than others?
Which other far away states are also considered to be less religious than others?

context: According to statistics collected by the Association of Religion Data Archives from 2010, about <a0_0><b4_0>34%<b4_0/><a0_0/> of Alaska residents were members of religious congregations. 100,960 people identified as <a1_0><b5_0>Evangelical Protestants<b5_0/><a1_0/>, 50,866 as Roman Catholic, and 32,550 as mainline Protestants. Roughly 4% are Mormon, 0.5% are Jewish, 1% are Muslim, 0.5% are Buddhist, and 0.5% are Hindu. The largest religious denominations in Alaska as of 2010[update] were the Catholic Church with 50,866 adherents, non-denominational Evangelical Protestants with 38,070 adherents, The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints with 32,170 adherents, and the Southern Baptist Convention with 19,891 adherents. Alaska has been identified, along with Pacific Northwest states <a3_0><b7_0><b8_0>Washington and Oregon<b8_0/><b7_0/><a3_0/>, as being the <a2_0><b6_0>least religious states of the USA<b6_0/><a2_0/>, in terms of church membership.
